Introduction

The EVM is a Turing complete virtual machine. EVM is intrinsically bound by gas ! Thus, the total amount of computation that can be done is intrinsically limited by the amount of gas provided !

Hence our strength could be our biggest weakness:

Problem:
An attacker can overflow the network with an infinite loop generating a network collapsing. 
Attacker willing to provide a massive gas (called infinite) in order to i.e: execute a simple contract: transfer amount x from beneficiary B to beneficiary A and transfer amount x’ to beneficiary B from A. 

If the attacker “invest” such a gas necessary to collapse the block generation (and Short a position from eth value - net halting (market cap value)), generating enough gas resource to repeat till Market Value gets to “Zero”. 

Consequence: Scalability compromised due to poor network performance and reliability. 

Possible Solution: 
If a contract (or dApp) spend X amount (to be discussed and determined) executing a cyclical, not complex (to be determined) algorithm - contract, must be reviewed by validators Node immediately.

Proposal:

Generate a mathematical (simple) model where max X gas for cyclical contracts is allow. 
Simulate TPS for EVM when hijacked from cyclical “simple”  smart contracts. 

Conclude if cyclical “infinite” gas smart contract could hijack EVM.

author: potuz
content: Sounds to me that you are proposing a fix for a problem that requires an infinite amount of funds to generate, and whose proposed fix will be trivially circumvented. For any simple in-protocol rule that you can come up with, the would-be attacker could simply make the loop slightly more complicated. I think gas price itself is already a mitigation for this attack: an attacker willing to burn massive amounts to break the network is better off buying all hashrate, or a vast majority of validators after the merge.
